1500 Portland Avenue
St, Paul 5, Minnesota
September 27, 1952
Mr. Seymour N. Siegel, President
National Association of
Educational Broadcasters
Station WHO
Municipal Broadcasting System
New York City, New York
Dear Sis
I ha mb been advised that a vacancy may occur in the
position of executive secretary of the National
Association of Educational Broadcasters.
In view of my long association with educational radio
and TV, my administrative experience, and my familiarity
with the special problems of the non-commercial station,
I believe I am particularly qualified for the position.
A personal data sheet enclosed with this letter outlines
the details of my professional background. My experience
actually dates back to 1926 when I first became a part-
time announcer for KUOM, University of Minnesota, then
identified as WLB. In 1928, I began work as a substitute
announcer for KSTP on a talent fee basis. My thirteen
years at KSTP as educational and public relations direc¬
tor gave me experience in every phase of regional station
operation, and so far as I know, with the exception of
network educational directors, I was the second man in
the nation to be placed in charge of public service pro¬
grams on a full time basis by any commercial station.
My network service brought me into daily contact with
nearly every important professional, educational, and
social welfare agency in the country. After the war I
returned to a managerial position v/ith NBC in charge
of package program sales, directing the contractual
arrangements and planning of all of the then NBC-owned
programs from Bill Stern to Kaltenborn, from Jinx
Palkenberg to Toscanini.
My academic experience dates from 1935 and the College
of St. Catherine to the University of Texas. During the
past twenty-five years I have participated in all of
the major educational radio conferences, helping to.
organize the School Broadcast Conference, the Association
for Education by Radio, and the University Association
for Professional Radio Education.
